statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Charlotte 63, Richmond 56
article.story: CHARLOTTE, N.C. (AP) -- The second time is a little easier. That's according to Charlotte coach Bobby Lutz, whose Charlotte 49ers defeated Richmond 64-47 in an Atlantic 10 game Wednesday night. Leemire Goldwire scored 19 points to lead the 49ers (15-9, 8-3 Atlantic 10) to their fourth-straight conference win. "The win was a wonderful carry over," said Lutz comparing this win to the 63-56 loss at Richmond on Jan. 28. "Being the new guy in the conference in our first year, it's so difficult to play a team the first time. The second time, you know what to expect and we didn't have to prepare as much." Charlotte took the lead for good early in the game, 7-6, on a Marcus Bennett jumper at the 14:15 mark. The 49ers led 27-18 at halftime after Curtis Withers led a fast break and scored with three seconds remaining. The 49ers took control of the game early in the second half as they hit 5-of-11 3-pointers to pull away despite the fact that Withers, an All-America candidate, picked up his fourth personal foul with 12:21 remaining. Charlotte, which used a full-court press much of the game led Richmond 33-29 with 13:58 in the second half after Richmond's Kevin Steenberge scored on a jumper for the Spiders. Charlotte then outscored the Spiders 19-6 to take a 54-35 lead with 6:21 to play. "In the second half, we made some big shots," Lutz said. "We took the press off when Withers got in foul trouble. Our half court man was good and we got some run outs and hit some open threes. We hit a huge stretch. Being up 13 on Richmond is like being up 20 on most teams. I was pleased with our defensive effort with their style of play. They can hurt you and we were much better tonight than the first game." Goldwire's points included four 3-pointers in the second half. Bennett scored 15 points for the 49ers and Withers had 14. Charlotte's Mitchell Baldwin, who broke his middle finger on his left hand against Wake Forest on Saturday, scored two points, dished out four assists and turned the ball over only one time. Three players scored nine points each for the Spiders (11-13, 4-7): Gaston Moliva, Oumar Sylla and Monty Sanders. The loss was the fifth straight for Richmond. "Charlotte's ability to score outside wore on us," said first-year Richmond coach Chris Mooney. "They have a variety of guys and each is difficult to guard. Charlotte was more aggressive this game. We had them on their heels the first time. Offensively, they are much quicker and they hit some transition baskets and scored points off our turnovers. We played tough, but I credit Charlotte. We were happy to beat them the first time since they are such a good program."
